metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Land cover map of the Heihe River Basin
metadata.description: The datasets of “Land Cover Map of Heihe River Basin” provide monthly land cover classification data in 2012-2013. The HJ-1/CCD data with both high spatial resolution (30 m) and high temporal (2 days) frequency was used to construct the time series data. The NDVI curves from the time series HJ-1/CCD data can depict the variation of typical land surface. Different land use type has different NDVI curve. Rules were set to extract every land use type information. The datasets of “Land Cover Map of Heihe River Basin” hold the traditional land use types including water bodies, urban and built-up, croplands, evergreen coniferous forests, deciduous broadleaf forests and so on. Crop type classification (including maize, spring wheat, highland barely, rape and so on), snow and ice and glaciers information updates, make the datasets more detailed. Compared with previous land cover map and other products, the classification result of the datasets is visually bette. Especially in middle stream, the accuracy of crop classification is quite high compared with the data from the ground campaign. The accuracy of land cover map of the datasets in 2012 was evaluated using very high spatial resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth and data from campaign, and the overall accuracy can be as high as 92.19%. In a word, the datasets of “Land Cover Map of Heihe River Basin” is not only high in overall accuracy, but also more detailed in crop fine classification. Furthermore, it updated some new classes like glaciers and snow. The datasets of “Land Cover Map of Heihe River Basin” are consequently the classification datasets with the highest accuracy and most detailed information up to now.

background: Land use refers to the description of human activities related to land, and it is a key factor in understanding the impact of human activities on regional and even global changes (Running, 2008). Its distribution and changes directly reflect human economic, social, and cultural activities. Land use data is a critical influencing factor in global change research and a key parameter for land surface process models, playing a crucial role in the improvement and development of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models (Foley et al., 2005; Jung et al., 2006). Currently, land use data has been widely applied in research areas such as biodiversity, carbon cycling, public health, crop yield estimation, urbanization processes, and forest resource monitoring (Shen Shuanghe et al., 2009; Zheng Sheng et al., 2011; Gong et al., 2013; Hall et al., 2011; Liang et al., 2010; Poulter et al., 2011). For a long time, with the development of remote sensing monitoring technology, in-depth research has been conducted on regional and even global land use and cover and their changes, resulting in numerous remote sensing classification and mapping methods for land use and cover (Yan Jianzong et al., 2005; Zhang Zengxiang et al., 2009). In recent years, domestic scholars have attempted classification methods using neural networks, tolerance rough sets, and biologically inspired optimization methods (Hasbagan et al., 2003, 2004; Liu Xiaoping et al., 2007). Currently, land cover classification methods using visible and near-infrared remote sensing images can be roughly divided into three categories based on the data used: methods based on single-phase high spatial resolution remote sensing data, methods based on time series of medium to low spatial resolution remote sensing data, and methods combining medium to high spatial resolution and medium to low resolution remote sensing data.
research objective: This article addresses the limitations of existing land use and land cover mapping products. It utilizes the high spatial and temporal resolution characteristics of the China Environment and Disaster Monitoring and Forecasting Small Satellite Constellation (HJ constellation) CCD data to develop a land cover classification method based on high spatial resolution time series data. This method leverages both the texture and spectral information from high spatial resolution data and the dynamic change information captured by high temporal resolution data, thereby improving the accuracy of land use mapping by utilizing the temporal differences of surface features.
challenges: This study proposes a land cover classification method based on time series HJ-1/CCD data from the perspectives of data selection (time series HJ-1/CCD data), classification methods (time series methods), and classification result verification (using high-resolution Google Earth data, time series data, and historical land use maps). Compared to traditional classification methods, this approach can effectively improve classification accuracy and the reliability of classification results while reducing costs associated with data acquisition and field surveys. However, this method also has the following issues: it requires more data than traditional methods (this study used 12 images over one year, and the data volume can be increased depending on the target); the geometric positioning and radiometric performance of HJ-1/CCD data are not the best at this stage, necessitating extensive data preprocessing to ensure image quality; and it is difficult to automate, requiring significant manual assistance.
methods: From the annual data of the study area, the best HJ-1/CCD image for each month is selected; thus, a total of 12 HJ-1/CCD images can be obtained for the study area, forming a time series of images. Data preprocessing mainly includes geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. This method uses the NDVI time series as input for the SVM classifier. This study employs the SVM classifier for classification, which requires sufficient training samples. After completing the SVM classification using NDVI, indices such as NDBI and NDWI are also introduced to distinguish between water, buildings, and vegetation. In the SVM classification, due to the small differences in NDVI time series changes between built-up land and tidal flats, most tidal flats are classified as built-up land; in the post-classification processing, the built-up land layer is extracted separately, and then, utilizing the high spatial resolution (30 m) of HJ-1/CCD data, texture information is used to differentiate between the two, improving the distinction between built-up land and tidal flats, resulting in the final outcome.
dataset: Therefore, this study will select HJ-1/CCD data as the input data for classification. The Chinese Environmental and Disaster Monitoring and Forecasting Small Satellite Constellation includes three satellites: HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C, among which 1A and 1B were launched on September 6, 2008. HJ-1A is equipped with two CCD cameras (referred to as HJ-1A/CCD1 and HJ-1A/CCD2) and one hyperspectral imager; HJ-1B is equipped with two CCD cameras (referred to as HJ-1B/CCD1 and HJ-1B/CCD2) and one infrared camera. Satellites 1A and 1B together carry a total of four CCD cameras with similar characteristics (collectively referred to as HJ-1/CCD), each CCD camera has four bands: red, green, blue, and near-infrared, with a swath width of 360 km and a spatial resolution of 30 m. The two CCD cameras on each satellite together form a sweeping imaging capability with a swath width of 700 km; thus, the two satellites together create an HJ-1/CCD data revisit cycle of 2 days, making it the shortest revisit cycle among high-resolution remote sensing data, comparable to mid-low resolution data such as MODIS. The atmospherically corrected HJ-1/CCD data will be processed according to the NDVI calculation formula to obtain NDVI images for each of the 12 months of the year.
findings: Through comparison, it can be found that methods based on time series HJ-1/CCD data have the following advantages: compared to traditional methods, the classification results based on time series HJ-1/CCD data are more consistent with actual conditions. From the two classification examples of Liaoning Dahuo Fang Reservoir and Qinghai Heiquan Reservoir, which are quite different, it can be seen that the classification method using time series HJ-1/CCD data has three advantages: the classification accuracy of water bodies, built-up land, forest land, and arable land has been improved; small water bodies and built-up land can be better identified using the time series HJ-1/CCD data method; and the identification accuracy of linear objects has also been effectively improved. Compared to traditional methods, the method based on time series HJ-1/CCD data has an improvement of about 10% in classification accuracy, and the kappa coefficient has increased by about 0.1.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. In addition, the classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary and are hardly suited for land-process modeling and applications at a river basin scale. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
methods: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method. Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: The confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classification accuracy, showing an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the HRB, which is quite higher than previous approaches. Furthermore, a ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

background: Accurate and up-to-date global land cover data sets are necessary for various global change research studies including climate change, biodiversity conservation, ecosystem assessment, and environmental modeling. In recent years, substantial advancement has been achieved in generating such data products. Two new global land cover data sets, Global Land Cover 2000 (GLC-2000) and MODerate resolution Imaging Spectrometer (MODIS) global land cover (MODIS land cover) have recently became available. The Joint Research Center (JRC) of the European Commission (EC) implemented the GLC-2000 project in partnership with more than 30 partner institutions around the world, using Satellite Pour l’Observation de la Terre (SPOT) VEGETATION 1-km satellite data (Fritz et al., 2003). Boston University prepared the MODIS land cover data using MODIS 1-km satellite data on board the Terra satellite (Friedl et al., 2002). Both data sets were prepared with the same fundamental goal: to improve our understanding of the extent and distribution of the major land cover types of the world. The information generated can be used for various applications including ecosystem and biodiversity assessments, climate change studies, and environmental modeling (Brown, Loveland, Ohlen, & Zhu, 1999; Giri, Defourny, & Shrestha, 2003; Loveland & Belward, 1997; Loveland, Estes, & Scepan, 1999; Reed, 1997).
research objective: We compared the recently available Global Land Cover 2000 (GLC-2000) and MODerate resolution Imaging Spectrometer (MODIS) global land cover data to evaluate the similarities and differences in methodologies and results, and to identify areas of spatial agreement and disagreement. Learning from past experience and building on the existing infrastructure (e.g., regional networks), further research is necessary to (1) reduce ambiguity in land cover definitions, (2) increase availability of improved spatial, spectral, radiometric, and geometric resolution satellite data, and (3) develop advanced classification algorithms.
challenges: Yet, we are far from producing geospatially consistent high-quality data at an operational level.
methods: We assume that the time difference of approximately 10 months between these two data sets is negligible in our comparative analysis. The GLC-2000 v1.1 data were downloaded from the worldwide web at URL http://www.gvm.sai.jrc.it/glc2000/ (last accessed 24 February 2004). We acquired the data in the Geographic Coordinate projection system, and reprojected it to Interrupted Goode Homolosine projection system. The MODIS land cover data were acquired from the Earth Observing System (EOS) Data Gateway, http://edcimswww.cr.usgs.gov/pub/imswelcome/ (last accessed 12 February 2004). The data, which are available in Hierarchical Data Format (HDF), were downloaded as tiles in Interrupted Goode Homolosine projection system. The individual tiles were mosaicked together for global coverage using MODIS Reprojection Tool 3.0 (available at URL http://lpdaac2.usgs.gov/landdaac/tools/modis/index.asp ). We used the IGBP layer of the MODIS land cover which contains 17 land cover classes. The latter was aggregated into 17 classes to make it consistent with the MODIS land cover classification system. Global area totals were computed for aggregated land cover classes and also for the IGBP classes. Pixel-by-pixel comparisons also were performed between the generalized (with eight classes) GLC-2000 and MODIS land cover data. The percent agreement and disagreement were calculated using the following equations: Overall percent agreement = (Σr i=1 Xi Yi / C18/C19) × 100 and Overall percent disagreement = 1 - (Σr i=1 Xi Yi / C18/C19) × 100.
dataset: These two global land cover data sets were prepared using different data sources, classification systems, and methodologies, but using the same spatial resolution (i.e., 1 km) satellite data.
findings: Our analysis shows a general agreement at the class aggregate level except for savannas/shrublands, and wetlands. The disagreement, however, increases when comparing detailed land cover classes. Similarly, percent agreement between the two data sets was found to be highly variable among biomes. The identified areas of spatial agreement and disagreement will be useful for both data producers and users.

background: It is very difficult to have remote sensing data with both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency; thus, two categories of land-use mapping methodology have been developed separately for coarser resolution and finer resolution data. Land use and land cover are the key factors for understanding the interactions between global changes and human activities, such as social, economic, and cultural activities. Moreover, it is one of the key parameters of land process modeling, and more accurate land use and land cover data will improve the accuracy of ecological, hydrological, and atmospheric models. Consequently, land use and land cover data are now widely used in many kinds of researches, such as biodiversity, carbon cycle, public health, crop yield estimation, urban sprawl, forest monitoring, and so on. Since land cover/use can be retrieved straightforwardly from remote sensing, many land cover/use mapping methods using remotely sensed data have been developed for the purposes of regional or global applications.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using the time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.
dataset: The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm). The time series data are composed of one dataset per month, so this time series of data can depict the variation of typical land surface.
findings: The overall accuracy for classification result using the time series of HJ-1/CCD data is 96.76% and the Kappa coefficient is 0.9423; the corresponding overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient for classification result using single Hj-1/CCD data are 87.59% and 0.8296 respectively. Compared with the classification result from single Hj-1/CCD data, the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is more than 10% and the Kappa coefficient is more than 0.1. The overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data are 83.78% and 0.8165 respectively; those using single HJ-1/CCD data are 70.82% and 0.665 respectively. It is similar to the comparison in the Dahuofang area that the overall accuracy of classification result using the time series HJ-1/CCD data is also 10% higher and Kappa coefficient is also 0.1 higher than that of classification result using single HJ-1/CCD data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that utilizes both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency for land-use mapping?
Example.Answer: A data collection method that utilizes both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency for land-use mapping is the use of time series HJ-1/CCD data. This approach involves selecting monthly HJ-1/CCD images to form a time series, where each month's best image is used to capture dynamic changes in land cover. This method enhances mapping accuracy by leveraging the detailed temporal and spatial information available in the HJ-1/CCD data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge in land-cover classification using optical remotely sensed imagery, particularly in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in land-cover classification using optical remotely sensed imagery, especially in arid regions, is the high uncertainty in differentiating between cropland and grassland categories, as well as among shrub, grassland, and forest categories. This uncertainty is exacerbated by the arid conditions, where vegetation cover may not meet the minimum threshold required for accurate classification, leading to potential errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.

Quantification.Question: How many HJ-1/CCD images are used annually for creating the time series dataset in land cover studies?
How many airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA during the HiWATER experiment in 2012?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multiscale dataset' in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A multiscale dataset in eco-hydrological research refers to the collection of data at different hierarchical levels and scales to capture diverse processes in the ecosystem. This includes data from instruments like eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, soil moisture sensors, and remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, all contributing to a comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes across scales.

Definition.Question: What does 'geometric and radiometric qualities' refer to in the context of remote sensing data usability?
Definition.Answer: Geometric and radiometric qualities in remote sensing data refer to the accuracy of the spatial representation and the fidelity of the spectral information captured in the images. Geometric quality ensures that the spatial dimensions and positioning of features are accurate, while radiometric quality relates to the precision of the brightness and color information. High-quality geometric and radiometric data are crucial for accurate data analysis and mapping, affecting the usability and reliability of remote sensing applications.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques utilized in the Heihe Watershed experiment compare to those used in generating the 黑河流域土地利用覆盖数据集 in terms of spatial resolution and temporal frequency?
Comparison.Answer: The Heihe Watershed experiment employs a multiscale dataset with instruments arranged at hierarchically nested scales, including LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and other advanced tools to capture eco-hydrological processes with high temporal frequency. In contrast, the 黑河流域土地利用覆盖数据集 uses HJ/CCD satellite data which offers a high spatial resolution of 30m and a revisit time of 2 days, enabling frequent temporal data collection for land use mapping with enhanced accuracy.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using HJ-1/CCD data for land-cover classification compared to using other global land-cover datasets like GLC-2000 and MODIS?
Comparison.Answer: Using HJ-1/CCD data presents challenges such as the need for extensive data handling due to larger data volumes and the requirement for significant preprocessing to address geometric and radiometric quality issues. In contrast, global datasets like GLC-2000 and MODIS face challenges related to consistency and classification accuracy across different biomes and land-cover types, often leading to discrepancies in areas with similar spectral characteristics.

Comparison.Question: In terms of classification accuracy, how does the use of time series HJ-1/CCD data compare to single-date remote sensing data in land-cover mapping?
Comparison.Answer: The use of time series HJ-1/CCD data significantly improves classification accuracy compared to single-date remote sensing data. Time series data offer a higher overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient, with improvements of over 10% in accuracy and 0.1 in Kappa coefficient, allowing for a more detailed and reliable representation of land cover changes over time.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of high-resolution and high-temporal-frequency remote sensing data improve the accuracy and detail of land cover mapping in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of high-resolution and high-temporal-frequency remote sensing data allows for capturing detailed dynamic changes in land cover, enhancing the classification accuracy. By using datasets like HJ-1/CCD, which provide high spatial and temporal resolution, researchers can improve the detail and precision in identifying various land cover types, such as distinguishing between cropland and grassland or small water bodies and buildings, which are often challenging with lower resolution data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to challenges in achieving high classification accuracy in land-cover mapping using remote-sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary factors include the variability in data quality and properties, the lack of a standardized approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements. Additionally, the highest uncertainty often arises between categories like cropland and grassland, especially in arid regions, due to differences in the minimum threshold for forest cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to obtain remote sensing data with both high spatial resolution and high temporal frequency for land-use mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is challenging because high spatial resolution data typically have a longer revisit cycle, making it difficult to capture frequent changes, while data with high temporal frequency often have coarser spatial resolution. This trade-off necessitates separate methodologies for different resolutions, complicating land-use mapping efforts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes limitations in the usability of HJ-1/CCD data for land-cover classification?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations are primarily due to the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data, which require extensive preprocessing. These issues increase the difficulty of using the data effectively and necessitate significant computational resources, making the process more complex and resource-intensive.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does employing a time series of higher spatial resolution data affect the accuracy and cost-efficiency of land cover classification methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using time series data with higher spatial resolution, such as HJ-1/CCD data, improves the accuracy of land cover classification by capturing dynamic changes in the surface, thereby enhancing both the precision and reliability of the classification. However, this approach requires more data, which increases computational load and necessitates extensive preprocessing, potentially raising costs and requiring more manual effort.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data in improving eco-hydrological modeling accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data can enhance eco-hydrological modeling accuracy by providing more detailed and varied information about land cover, thus reducing uncertainties in classification. This approach allows for more precise mapping of crop and vegetation categories, which is crucial in arid regions where vegetation classification is challenging. However, it demands significant data processing capabilities and expertise in managing diverse data sources.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on the classification accuracy when using a combination of traditional land cover datasets and new methodologies involving HJ-1/CCD data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Combining traditional land cover datasets with new methodologies using HJ-1/CCD data leads to improved classification accuracy, as these methods leverage the strengths of higher spatial and temporal resolution data. Goal Orientation.Question: Why is the development of a time series-based land cover mapping method using HJ-1/CCD data considered significant?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The development of a time series-based land cover mapping method using HJ-1/CCD data is significant because it can greatly improve land cover mapping accuracy. Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in processing remote sensing data to improve land cover classification accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key steps involve selecting the best monthly HJ-1/CCD images to form a time series for the research area. Preprocessing includes geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. The NDVI time series is used as input for the SVM classifier, and additional indices like NDBI and NDWI are used to differentiate between water, buildings, and vegetation. Post-classification processing involves using texture information to improve differentiation between buildings and tidal flats.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges faced in using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping, and how can these be overcome?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The challenges include the need for large amounts of data and increased computational load, as well as the geometric and radiometric limitations of HJ-1/CCD data that require extensive preprocessing. These can be overcome by ensuring thorough data preprocessing and using advanced techniques like SVM classifiers and texture analysis to improve classification accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What data preprocessing steps enable the use of time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover classification with higher accuracy?
Enablement.Answer: Data preprocessing involves selecting the best HJ-1/CCD image for each month, performing geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. These steps ensure that the data are suitable for input into classification algorithms, thereby enhancing accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What observational strategies enable the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert system?
Enablement.Answer: Observational strategies include hierarchically nested instrumentation, such as flux towers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing missions. Expectation.Answer: While time series data from satellites with higher spatial and temporal resolutions are expected to enhance classification accuracy by capturing surface dynamics over time, limitations include the increased computational load, extensive data requirements, and the need for significant preprocessing. Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a summary of the classification methods used for land-cover mapping in the Heihe River Basin and how they address the challenges of distinguishing between cropland and grassland.
Request/Directive.Answer: The classification methods used for land-cover mapping in the Heihe River Basin involve utilizing a mosaic of Landsat/TM imagery and HJ-1/CCD images, which are corrected through image-to-image registration. The methodology includes converting DN values to TOA radiance, removing atmospheric effects to obtain surface reflectance, and creating time series mosaics. This approach addresses the challenges of distinguishing between cropland and grassland by using high-resolution images and multiple classifiers, leading to improved accuracy and a classification accuracy of over 90%.
